0.81.text:
Much Ado About Nothing
by William Shakespeare

10.30.text:
Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a
Messenger

14.58.text:
LEONATO
I learn in this letter that Don Peter of Arragon

19.76.text:
Messenger
He is very near by this: he was not three

22.29.text:
leagues off
when I left him.

23.67.text:
LEONATO
How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?

26.16.text:
Messenger
But few of any sort, and none of name.

29.24.text:
LEONATO
A victory is twice itself when the achiever

33.11.text:
I find here that Don Peter hath
bestowed much honour on a young Florentine

38.77.text:
Messenger
Much deserved on his part and equally remembered

42.99.text:
by
Don Pedro: he hath borne himself beyond the

46.01.text:
promise of his age, doing, in the figure of
a lamb,

49.04.text:
the feats of a lion: he hath indeed better
bettered expectation than you must expect

53.63.text:
of me to
tell you how.

54.72.text:
LEONATO
He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very

58.66.text:
Messenger
I have already delivered him letters, and

61.22.text:
there
appears much joy in him; even so much that

64.21.text:
joy could
not show itself modest enough without a badge

68.57.text:
LEONATO
Did he break out into tears?

71.17.text:
LEONATO
A kind overflow of kindness: there are no

74.47.text:
faces
truer than those that are so washed.

77.48.text:
How much
better is it to weep at joy than to joy at

81.70.text:
BEATRICE
I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned

85.14.text:
Messenger
I know none of that name, lady: there was

87.83.text:
none such
in the army of any sort.

89.70.text:
LEONATO
What is he that you ask for, niece?

92.01.text:
HERO
My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

95.48.text:
Messenger
O, he's returned; and as pleasant as ever

98.41.text:
BEATRICE
He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged

100.79.text:
Cupid at the flight; and my uncle's fool,
reading

103.72.text:
the challenge, subscribed for Cupid, and challenged
him at the bird-bolt.

108.79.text:
I pray you, how many hath he
killed and eaten in these wars?

113.02.text:
But how many hath
he killed? for indeed I promised to eat all

118.30.text:
LEONATO
Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too

121.78.text:
much;
but he'll be meet with you, I doubt it not.

124.31.text:
Messenger
He hath done good service, lady, in these

127.94.text:
BEATRICE
You had musty victual, and he hath holp to

129.82.text:
eat it:
he is a very valiant trencherman; he hath

134.99.text:
Messenger
And a good soldier too, lady.

136.87.text:
BEATRICE
And a good soldier to a lady: but what is

140.64.text:
Messenger
A lord to a lord, a man to a man; stuffed

145.44.text:
BEATRICE
It is so, indeed; he is no less than a stuffed

149.70.text:
man:
but for the stuffing,—well, we are all mortal.

154.24.text:
LEONATO
You must not, sir, mistake my niece.

157.80.text:
There is a
kind of merry war betwixt Signior Benedick

161.21.text:
and her:
they never meet but there's a skirmish of

165.15.text:
BEATRICE
Alas! he gets nothing by that.

168.53.text:
In our last
conflict four of his five wits went halting

172.18.text:
off, and
now is the whole man governed with one: so

176.03.text:
that if
he have wit enough to keep himself warm, let

179.01.text:
him
bear it for a difference between himself and

181.36.text:
his
horse; for it is all the wealth that he hath

183.76.text:
left,
to be known a reasonable creature.

188.97.text: He hath every month a new sworn brother.

192.67.text:
BEATRICE
Very easily possible: he wears his faith but

195.66.text:
as
the fashion of his hat; it ever changes with

199.36.text:
Messenger
I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your

203.39.text:
BEATRICE
No; an he were, I would burn my study.

206.01.text:
But, I pray
you, who is his companion?

209.29.text:
Is there no young
squarer now that will make a voyage with him

213.02.text:
Messenger
He is most in the company of the right noble

217.47.text:
BEATRICE
O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease:

220.91.text:
he
is sooner caught than the pestilence, and

226.00.text:
God help the noble Claudio! if
he have caught the Benedick, it will cost

230.28.text:
him a
thousand pound ere a' be cured.

232.44.text:
Messenger
I will hold friends with you, lady.

236.56.text:
LEONATO
You will never run mad, niece.

239.08.text:
BEATRICE
No, not till a hot January.

244.32.text:
Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK,
and BALTHASAR

250.65.text:
DON PEDRO
Good Signior Leonato, you are come to meet

254.35.text:
your
trouble: the fashion of the world is to avoid

259.98.text:
LEONATO
Never came trouble to my house in the likeness

262.77.text:
of
your grace: for trouble being gone, comfort

265.82.text:
should
remain; but when you depart from me, sorrow

269.18.text:
abides
and happiness takes his leave.

271.13.text:
DON PEDRO
You embrace your charge too willingly.

273.15.text:
I think this
is your daughter.

275.33.text:
LEONATO
Her mother hath many times told me so.

278.18.text:
BENEDICK
Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her?

280.76.text:
LEONATO
Signior Benedick, no; for then were you a

283.97.text:
DON PEDRO
You have it full, Benedick: we may guess by

287.05.text:
this
what you are, being a man.

293.35.text:
Be happy, lady; for you are like an
honourable father.

296.96.text:
BENEDICK
If Signior Leonato be her father, she would

300.01.text:
not
have his head on her shoulders for all Messina,

302.65.text:
as
like him as she is.

303.93.text:
BEATRICE
I wonder that you will still be talking, Signior

309.40.text:
BENEDICK
What, my dear Lady Disdain! are you yet living?

314.24.text:
BEATRICE
Is it possible disdain should die while she

317.30.text:
hath
such meet food to feed it as Signior Benedick?

321.67.text:
Courtesy itself must convert to disdain, if
you come

324.90.text:
BENEDICK
Then is courtesy a turncoat.

327.98.text:
But it is certain I
am loved of all ladies, only you excepted:

331.75.text:
and I
would I could find in my heart that I had

334.90.text:
not a hard
heart; for, truly, I love none.

338.65.text:
BEATRICE
A dear happiness to women: they would else

341.85.text:
have
been troubled with a pernicious suitor.

344.35.text:
I thank God
and my cold blood, I am of your humour for

348.07.text:
that: I
had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than

350.73.text:
a man
swear he loves me.

352.51.text:
BENEDICK
God keep your ladyship still in that mind!

355.53.text:
so some
gentleman or other shall 'scape a predestinate

359.72.text:
BEATRICE
Scratching could not make it worse, an 'twere

362.37.text:
such
a face as yours were.

363.96.text:
BENEDICK
Well, you are a rare parrot-teacher.

366.88.text:
BEATRICE
A bird of my tongue is better than a beast

370.37.text:
BENEDICK
I would my horse had the speed of your tongue,

375.17.text:
But keep your way, i' God's
name; I have done.

378.08.text:
BEATRICE
You always end with a jade's trick: I know

382.19.text:
DON PEDRO
That is the sum of all, Leonato.

385.30.text:
Signior Claudio
and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato

391.70.text:
I tell him we shall stay here at
the least a month; and he heartily prays some

398.27.text:
I dare swear he is no
hypocrite, but prays from his heart.

403.14.text:
LEONATO
If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn.

407.89.text:
Let me bid you welcome, my lord: being reconciled
to

410.77.text: the prince your brother, I owe you all duty.

413.04.text:
DON JOHN
I thank you: I am not of many words, but I

419.21.text:
LEONATO
Please it your grace lead on?

420.53.text:
DON PEDRO
Your hand, Leonato; we will go together.

424.05.text: Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO

426.79.text:
CLAUDIO
Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of

430.39.text:
BENEDICK
I noted her not; but I looked on her.

432.80.text:
CLAUDIO
Is she not a modest young lady?

434.65.text:
BENEDICK
Do you question me, as an honest man should

437.48.text:
do, for
my simple true judgment; or would you have

440.79.text:
me speak
after my custom, as being a professed tyrant

444.84.text:
CLAUDIO
No; I pray thee speak in sober judgment.

448.19.text:
BENEDICK
Why, i' faith, methinks she's too low for

451.36.text:
a high
praise, too brown for a fair praise and too

455.25.text:
little
for a great praise: only this commendation

458.33.text:
I can
afford her, that were she other than she is,

461.55.text:
she
were unhandsome; and being no other but as

464.12.text:
she is, I
do not like her.

466.30.text:
CLAUDIO
Thou thinkest I am in sport: I pray thee tell

469.28.text:
me
truly how thou likest her.

470.92.text:
BENEDICK
Would you buy her, that you inquire after

474.30.text:
CLAUDIO
Can the world buy such a jewel?

475.45.text:
BENEDICK
Yea, and a case to put it into.

479.60.text:
But speak you this
with a sad brow? or do you play the flouting

483.65.text:
Jack,
to tell us Cupid is a good hare-finder and

488.59.text:
Come, in what key shall a man take
you, to go in the song?

492.91.text:
CLAUDIO
In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that

496.18.text:
BENEDICK
I can see yet without spectacles and I see

499.31.text:
no such
matter: there's her cousin, an she were not

503.65.text:
possessed with a fury, exceeds her as much
in beauty

506.64.text: as the first of May doth the last of December.

508.75.text:
But I
hope you have no intent to turn husband, have

514.63.text:
CLAUDIO
I would scarce trust myself, though I had

516.94.text:
sworn the
contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

521.56.text:
In faith, hath not the world
one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion?

527.53.text:
Shall I never see a bachelor of three-score
again?

531.42.text:
Go to, i' faith; an thou wilt needs thrust
thy neck

534.98.text:
into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh
away

539.81.text: Look Don Pedro is returned to seek you.

543.64.text:
DON PEDRO
What secret hath held you here, that you followed

547.75.text:
BENEDICK
I would your grace would constrain me to tell.

550.88.text:
DON PEDRO
I charge thee on thy allegiance.

553.81.text:
BENEDICK
You hear, Count Claudio: I can be secret as

557.95.text:
a dumb
man; I would have you think so; but, on my

561.56.text: allegiance, mark you this, on my allegiance.

570.23.text: now that is your grace's part.

571.72.text:
Mark how short his answer is;—With Hero,
Leonato's

577.69.text:
CLAUDIO
If this were so, so were it uttered.

580.59.text:
BENEDICK
Like the old tale, my lord: 'it is not so,

583.92.text:
nor
'twas not so, but, indeed, God forbid it should

588.62.text:
CLAUDIO
If my passion change not shortly, God forbid

592.25.text:
DON PEDRO
Amen, if you love her; for the lady is very

596.78.text:
CLAUDIO
You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.

598.70.text:
DON PEDRO
By my troth, I speak my thought.

601.00.text:
CLAUDIO
And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.

603.48.text:
BENEDICK
And, by my two faiths and troths, my lord,

607.12.text:
CLAUDIO
That I love her, I feel.

608.64.text:
DON PEDRO
That she is worthy, I know.

610.69.text:
BENEDICK
That I neither feel how she should be loved

613.03.text:
nor
know how she should be worthy, is the opinion

615.45.text:
that
fire cannot melt out of me: I will die in

619.64.text:
DON PEDRO
Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the

624.06.text:
CLAUDIO
And never could maintain his part but in the

627.19.text:
BENEDICK
That a woman conceived me, I thank her; that

630.92.text:
she
brought me up, I likewise give her most humble

633.99.text:
thanks: but that I will have a recheat winded
in my

637.53.text:
forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible
baldrick,

643.62.text:
Because I will not do
them the wrong to mistrust any, I will do

647.29.text:
myself the
right to trust none; and the fine is, for

651.85.text:
the which
I may go the finer, I will live a bachelor.

655.61.text:
DON PEDRO
I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with

661.69.text:
BENEDICK
With anger, with sickness, or with hunger,

664.82.text:
my lord,
not with love: prove that ever I lose more

669.64.text:
blood
with love than I will get again with drinking,

672.27.text:
pick
out mine eyes with a ballad-maker's pen and

675.31.text:
hang me
up at the door of a brothel-house for the

678.89.text:
DON PEDRO
Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith,

682.56.text:
thou
wilt prove a notable argument.

684.50.text:
BENEDICK
If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and

688.32.text:
shoot
at me; and he that hits me, let him be clapped

691.80.text:
on
the shoulder, and called Adam.

693.40.text:
DON PEDRO
Well, as time shall try: 'In time the savage

699.54.text:
BENEDICK
The savage bull may; but if ever the sensible

702.56.text:
Benedick bear it, pluck off the bull's horns
and set

705.45.text:
them in my forehead: and let me be vilely
painted,

709.73.text:
and in such great letters as they write 'Here
is

712.02.text:
good horse to hire,' let them signify under
my sign

716.18.text: 'Here you may see Benedick the married man.'

719.24.text:
CLAUDIO
If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be

722.80.text:
DON PEDRO
Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver

725.24.text:
in
Venice, thou wilt quake for this shortly.

728.27.text:
BENEDICK
I look for an earthquake too, then.

730.79.text:
DON PEDRO
Well, you temporize with the hours.

734.27.text:
In the
meantime, good Signior Benedick, repair to

737.15.text:
Leonato's: commend me to him and tell him
I will

740.84.text:
not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath
made

745.32.text:
BENEDICK
I have almost matter enough in me for such

748.05.text:
an
embassage; and so I commit you—

750.96.text:
CLAUDIO
To the tuition of God: From my house, if I

754.61.text: The sixth of July: Your loving friend, Benedick.

757.52.text:
BENEDICK
Nay, mock not, mock not.

761.56.text:
The body of your
discourse is sometime guarded with fragments,

765.29.text:
and
the guards are but slightly basted on neither:

768.51.text:
ere
you flout old ends any further, examine your

771.84.text: conscience: and so I leave you.

776.74.text:
CLAUDIO
My liege, your highness now may do me good.

779.03.text:
DON PEDRO
My love is thine to teach: teach it but how,

782.73.text:
And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn
Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

787.50.text:
CLAUDIO
Hath Leonato any son, my lord?

789.68.text:
DON PEDRO
No child but Hero; she's his only heir.

796.87.text:
When you went onward on this ended action,
I look'd upon her with a soldier's eye,

801.57.text:
That liked, but had a rougher task in hand
Than to drive liking to the name of love:

807.65.text:
But now I am return'd and that war-thoughts
Have left their places vacant, in their rooms

813.37.text:
Come thronging soft and delicate desires,
All prompting me how fair young Hero is,

818.85.text: Saying, I liked her ere I went to wars.

821.27.text:
DON PEDRO
Thou wilt be like a lover presently

824.15.text: And tire the hearer with a book of words.

827.77.text:
If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it,
And I will break with her and with her father,

835.76.text:
Was't not to this end
That thou began'st to twist so fine a story?

840.80.text:
CLAUDIO
How sweetly you do minister to love,

843.08.text: That know love's grief by his complexion!

846.48.text:
But lest my liking might too sudden seem,
I would have salved it with a longer treatise.

850.77.text:
DON PEDRO
What need the bridge much broader than the

855.26.text: The fairest grant is the necessity.

858.04.text:
Look, what will serve is fit: 'tis once, thou
lovest,

862.85.text: And I will fit thee with the remedy.

865.30.text:
I know we shall have revelling to-night:
I will assume thy part in some disguise

871.01.text:
And tell fair Hero I am Claudio,
And in her bosom I'll unclasp my heart

878.22.text:
And take her hearing prisoner with the force
And strong encounter of my amorous tale:

884.44.text:
Then after to her father will I break;
And the conclusion is, she shall be thine.

892.03.text: In practise let us put it presently.

900.37.text:
Enter LEONATO and ANTONIO, meeting
LEONATO

904.70.text: Where is my cousin, your son?

908.46.text:
ANTONIO
He is very busy about it.

910.94.text:
But, brother, I can tell
you strange news that you yet dreamt not of.

917.69.text:
ANTONIO
As the event stamps them: but they have a

920.22.text:
good
cover; they show well outward.

922.46.text:
The prince and Count
Claudio, walking in a thick-pleached alley

926.91.text:
in mine
orchard, were thus much overheard by a man

930.84.text:
of mine:
the prince discovered to Claudio that he loved

934.61.text:
my
niece your daughter and meant to acknowledge

937.47.text:
it
this night in a dance: and if he found her

940.26.text:
accordant, he meant to take the present time
by the

942.80.text: top and instantly break with you of it.

945.36.text:
LEONATO
Hath the fellow any wit that told you this?

947.87.text:
ANTONIO
A good sharp fellow: I will send for him;

952.32.text:
LEONATO
No, no; we will hold it as a dream till it

955.09.text:
appear
itself: but I will acquaint my daughter withal,

958.46.text:
that she may be the better prepared for an
answer,

962.28.text: Go you and tell her of it.

966.66.text: Cousins, you know what you have to do.

968.70.text:
O, I cry you
mercy, friend; go you with me, and I will

972.64.text: Good cousin, have a care this busy time.

981.13.text:
Enter DON JOHN and CONRADE
CONRADE

983.43.text:
What the good-year, my lord! why are you thus
out

987.67.text:
DON JOHN
There is no measure in the occasion that breeds;

991.80.text: therefore the sadness is without limit.

995.74.text:
DON JOHN
And when I have heard it, what blessing brings

999.91.text:
CONRADE
If not a present remedy, at least a patient

1003.28.text:
DON JOHN
I wonder that thou, being, as thou sayest

1006.77.text:
thou art,
born under Saturn, goest about to apply a

1010.41.text:
moral
medicine to a mortifying mischief.

1013.89.text:
I cannot hide
what I am: I must be sad when I have cause

1018.78.text:
and smile
at no man's jests, eat when I have stomach

1023.55.text:
and wait
for no man's leisure, sleep when I am drowsy

1028.34.text:
and
tend on no man's business, laugh when I am

1033.20.text:
merry and
claw no man in his humour.

1036.16.text:
CONRADE
Yea, but you must not make the full show of

1038.75.text:
this
till you may do it without controlment.

1042.23.text:
You have of
late stood out against your brother, and he

1045.38.text:
hath
ta'en you newly into his grace; where it is

1049.26.text:
impossible you should take true root but by
the

1052.11.text:
fair weather that you make yourself: it is
needful

1055.00.text: that you frame the season for your own harvest.

1058.18.text:
DON JOHN
I had rather be a canker in a hedge than a

1061.02.text:
rose in
his grace, and it better fits my blood to

1064.76.text:
be
disdained of all than to fashion a carriage

1067.04.text:
to rob
love from any: in this, though I cannot be

1070.89.text:
said to
be a flattering honest man, it must not be

1074.09.text:
denied
but I am a plain-dealing villain.

1078.38.text:
I am trusted with
a muzzle and enfranchised with a clog; therefore

1085.10.text:
I
have decreed not to sing in my cage.

1089.16.text:
If I had my
mouth, I would bite; if I had my liberty,

1092.74.text:
I would do
my liking: in the meantime let me be that

1096.73.text:
I am and
seek not to alter me.

1099.63.text:
CONRADE
Can you make no use of your discontent?

1101.86.text:
DON JOHN
I make all use of it, for I use it only.

1110.22.text:
BORACHIO
I came yonder from a great supper: the prince

1113.90.text:
your
brother is royally entertained by Leonato:

1117.41.text:
and I
can give you intelligence of an intended marriage.

1120.09.text:
DON JOHN
Will it serve for any model to build mischief

1124.55.text:
What is he for a fool that betroths himself
to

1127.75.text:
BORACHIO
Marry, it is your brother's right hand.

1137.13.text:
And who, and who? which way looks
he?

1139.75.text:
BORACHIO
Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.

1143.06.text:
DON JOHN
A very forward March-chick!

1147.74.text:
BORACHIO
Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was

1150.56.text:
smoking a
musty room, comes me the prince and Claudio,

1154.23.text:
hand
in hand in sad conference: I whipt me behind

1157.55.text:
the
arras; and there heard it agreed upon that

1159.83.text:
the
prince should woo Hero for himself, and having

1162.93.text: obtained her, give her to Count Claudio.

1165.54.text:
DON JOHN
Come, come, let us thither: this may prove

1170.18.text:
That young start-up hath all the
glory of my overthrow: if I can cross him

1175.90.text:
any way, I
bless myself every way.

1179.98.text: You are both sure, and will assist me?

1181.94.text:
CONRADE
To the death, my lord.

1183.40.text:
DON JOHN
Let us to the great supper: their cheer is

1186.45.text:
the
greater that I am subdued.

1188.68.text:
Would the cook were of
my mind!

1191.11.text: Shall we go prove what's to be done?

1193.45.text:
BORACHIO
We'll wait upon your lordship.
